So just a quick rev- review to remind you,
as we said- as we looked at the blockchain network, basically, um,
the balance of Bitcoins that I own is basically is held in
these unspent transaction outputs that correspond to addresses that belong to me.
What does belong to me mean?
Belong to me means that I have
the secret key that corresponds to the public key of those addresses.
Now, other blockchains actually don't use the UTXO model.
For example, the Ethereum blockchain actually has accounts where every account,
uh, holds a value.
So I have, again, it's all based on signatures.
So my, I have an account that corresponds to a public key and a secret key,
but there is a value associated with that- with that account written on the blockchain.
And when I want to spend funds, I,
I sign a transaction that subtracts or
adds fund- funds to the amounts available in the account.
So it's not a collection of UTXOs,
but rather explicit accounting of how much money every address has.
Yeah. So every address,
as we say, has an associated value,
and the transaction just moves values between, um, between addresses.
So these are kind of different ways of representing data on the blockchain,
you know, either accounts or UTXOs.
It turns out UTXOs require less memory on the part of the miners but,
um, um, um, but are less flexible than accounts.
So for example, with an account system,
you can just look on the block chain and immediately know
how much value is associated with a particular address.
In the UTXO model to figure out how much value is associated with an address,
you have to go and sum up all the values,
of across all UTXOs in the blockchains that correspond to that address.
Yeah. So there are trade-offs between these two ways to represent value,
different blockchains as you can see,
do it- uh, do it differently.

helps us manage our assets, okay?
So what does a wallet do?
Well, you know, it stores all of my secret signing keys.

when I want to spend funds or receive funds, basically,

sends funds to me.
